terms.name: Macroeconomics
terms.desc: Is the branch of economics dealing with the performance, structure, behaviour and decision making of an economy as a whole.

terms.name: Microeconomics
terms.desc: Is the branch of economics involving the behaviour of individuals and firms in making decisions regarding the allocation of limited resources.

terms.name: Factors of Production
terms.desc: What effects the production of a product, good or service.

terms.name: Capital
terms.desc: Man-made physical goods used to produce other goods and services.

terms.name: Enterprise
terms.desc: People who come up with the initial idea (entrepenurs). They risk their own resources.

terms.name: Land
terms.desc: The natural resource on the planet.

terms.name: Labour
terms.desc: The human input into the production process. The UK has about 58 million people of which approximately 35 million are of working age.

terms.name: Productivity
terms.desc: Output per worker per period of time.

terms.name: Sustainability
terms.desc: Having a system where all factors are sustainable.

terms.name: Primary
terms.desc: Where the extraction of raw materials takes place.

terms.name: Secondary
terms.desc: Where raw materials are manufactured into goods.

terms.name: Tertiary
terms.desc: The service sector.

terms.name: Economies of Scale
terms.desc: The larger the company is, the cheaper the cost of production.

terms.name: Cost
terms.desc: What money is spent on land, labour, materials etc.

terms.name: Revenue
terms.desc: The money that is made.

terms.name: Profit
terms.desc: Total revenue - total cost = PROFIT.

terms.name: Demand
terms.desc: When students ask for cake.

terms.name: Lack of Supply
terms.desc: When Poynsenby doesn't provide cake.

terms.name: Supply
terms.desc: When Poynsenby provides cake.

terms.name: Factors that affect demand
terms.desc: Factors that can change the demand rate for diffrent goods.

terms.name: Population
terms.desc: An increase in population leads to an increase of demand.

terms.name: Advertising
terms.desc: An increase in advertising will make customers more likely to buy a product.

terms.name: Substitutes
terms.desc: If a substitute good is cheaper than the original people are more likely to buy it.

terms.name: Income
terms.desc: If income rises so does demand.

terms.name: Fashion and Trends
terms.desc: If something is fashionable or trendy, demand for that product rises.

terms.name: Interest Rates
terms.desc: If interest rates rise people borrowing have less money to spend so demand falls.

terms.name: Complements
terms.desc: If the price of a product falls, demand for another may rise.

terms.name: Market Economy
terms.desc: An economy where all the resources are allocates by the forces of demand and supply with a price attached.

terms.name: Basic Economic Problem
terms.desc: Wants are infinite but resources are not.

terms.name: Market
terms.desc: Where buyers and sellers exchange goods, this doesn't have to be face to face.

terms.name: Output
terms.desc: The number of goods or servics produced by a firm.

terms.name: Fixed Costs
terms.desc: Costs that do not vary with output.

terms.name: Variable Costs
terms.desc: Costs that vary directly with output.

terms.name: Total Revenue
terms.desc: The amount a firm receives from selling its product.

terms.name: Technology
terms.desc: Better tech means better production.

terms.name: Monopoly
terms.desc: A situation in which there is only one firm selling in a market.

terms.name: Monopoly Power
terms.desc: Where a firm has 25% of the market share.

terms.name: Merger
terms.desc: When two companies become one.

terms.name: Branding
terms.desc: The apperance of the company. This can be used to create brand loyalty.

terms.name: Opportunity Cost
terms.desc: The next best alternative faregone when making a choice- what you give up when you make a choice.

terms.name: Production
terms.desc: The process of combining scarce resources to make an output.

terms.name: Productivity
terms.desc: Output per worker per period of time.

terms.name: Takeover
terms.desc: Where one company buys another.

terms.name: Intergration
terms.desc: This occurs when the two firms come together through either a merger or takeover.

terms.name: Cost barriers
terms.desc: Large firms gain internal economies of scale meaning their average cost is low.

terms.name: Subsidies
terms.desc: The government gives you money.

terms.name: Weather
terms.desc: Seasons and weather can affect production.

terms.name: Goods
terms.desc: Are tangible items - things you touch.

terms.name: Services
terms.desc: Something that is provided for you. It is intangible.

terms.name: Needs
terms.desc: Something needed for survival.

terms.name: Wants
terms.desc: Something you would like but is not necessary.

terms.name: Resources
terms.desc: Something to produce output.

terms.name: Adaptive expectations
terms.desc: A theory of how people form their views about the future that assumes they do so using past trends and the errors in their own earlier predictions.

terms.name: Absolute advantage
terms.desc: If one person, firm or country can produce more of something with the same amount of effort and resources, they have an absolute advantage.

terms.name: Amortisation
terms.desc: The running down or payment of a loan by instalments.

terms.name: Assets
terms.desc: An resource with economic value that the owner hopes will provide future benefit.

terms.name: Autarky
terms.desc: The idea that a country should be self-sufficient and not participate in international trade.

terms.name: Barter
terms.desc: Paying for goods or services with other goods or services.

terms.name: Basis Point
terms.desc: One one-hundreth of one percent.

terms.name: Buyer's Market
terms.desc: A market where supply is high and prices are low. The opposite to a Seller's Market.

terms.name: Closed Economy
terms.desc: An economy that does not take part in international trade.

terms.name: Command Economy
terms.desc: When a government controls all economic activity.

terms.name: Commoditisation
terms.desc: The process of becoming a commodity.

terms.name: Commodity
terms.desc: A physical substance (food, grains, metals) which is interchangeable with another product of the same type.

terms.name: Compound Interest
terms.desc: Interest payed on the initial price and also on interest gained.

terms.name: Contagion
terms.desc: Interest payed on the initial price and also on interest gained.

terms.name: Default
terms.desc: Failure to fulfil the terms of a loan agreement.

terms.name: Deficit
terms.desc: When more money goes out than comes in.

terms.name: Disinflation
terms.desc: When the rate of inflation falls. NOT DEFLATION.

terms.name: Dividend
terms.desc: The part of a company's profit distributed to shareholders.

terms.name: Dominant Firm
terms.desc: The same as a monopoly. When a firm has the ability to set its own prices in the market.

terms.name: Dumping
terms.desc: Selling something for less than the cost of producing it.

terms.name: ECB
terms.desc: The European Central Bank.

terms.name: Econometrics
terms.desc: Mathematics and sophisticated computing applied to economics.

terms.name: NAFTA
terms.desc: Short for North American Free-Trade Agreement.

terms.name: NAIRU
terms.desc: The non-accelerating-inflation rate of unemployment.

terms.name: Loan
terms.desc: A borrowed sum of money that is expected to be paid back with intrest.

terms.name: Economic growth
terms.desc: Growth in output of the economy over time.
